question: It is true that fixed partitioning divides memory into fixed-sized blocks before running any program.
It is false that in fixed partitioning, programs can be loaded into partitions of any size, based on their needs.
It is true that variable partitioning eliminates internal fragmentation but may cause external fragmentation.
It is false that in variable partitioning, memory partitions are of fixed size, regardless of program size.
It is true that the bitmap method uses a sequence of bits to track free and occupied memory blocks.
It is false that the bitmap method is the fastest way to allocate free memory due to its simplicity.
It is true that the linked list method uses pointers to link free memory blocks together in a free list.
It is false that the linked list method requires no additional memory for storing pointers.
It is true that fixed partitioning leads to internal fragmentation when a program is smaller than the allocated partition.
It is false that variable partitioning causes no fragmentation, as it can result in external fragmentation over time.
